Cedric Beust wrote:

> In this case, I would recommend breaking down your test class in a parent
> class for all the test methods that don't need this file and a subclass for
> all the test methods that do need this file.  Then you can put the reparse
> of your file in setUp(), which -- as someone said earlier -- makes the
> intent obvious.

That leads to class proliferation that makes it hard to locate the test 
I want when I want it. I have to guess which file is likely to contain 
the test for which functionality based on arbitrary details like what 
fixtures it uses. As it is, I know that tests for the Element class can 
be found in the ElementTest class, tests for attributes go in the 
Attribute class, tests for XPath go in the XPathTest class. Not perfect, 
but it  makes it a lot easier to find what I'm looking far.

A few minutes ago on another mailing list, somebody asked me a question 
about a complicated detail in XPath parsing. Basically he proposed 
optimizing evaluation by using a  "theorem" I knew to be false. I didn't 
remember exactly why the theorem was false, but I knew I had a 
counterexample in a test case. Sure enough, a quick glance through the 
XPathTest class revealed the counterexample. Now if I had had to hunt 
through 12 different classes to try to find the right test case, I still 
could have done it; but it would have taken a lot longer.

Test suites serve double duty as documentation for a program. They serve 
this task better if they're cleanly organized by functionality rather 
than by implementation details like which fixtures they do and don't set up.
